advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME IN GERMAN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Part of a software advert<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Despite the M20 was neither software nor hardware compatible with any other computer, Olivetti had to prove that it had more computing power at a smaller pice than any competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SCARY...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you believe it?! She is learning how to play flute (mini flute?) with her TO7... The father seems to be a kind of lunatic...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: 16 bit HuC6260 Video Color Encoder, 16 bit HuC6270A Video Display Controller
computer.description:
Released in 1989, the TurboGrafx-16 was the American name for the PC Engine.
Originally marketed as a competitor for the NES, it sold well initially, but never achieved the same success the PC Engine enjoyed in Japan.
Games for the TG-16 came on credit card sized TurboChips, similar to the cards that could be used on the original Master System.
TG-16 games have a distinct style, featuring large, colourful sprites, which still hold up well today. The 16 attached to the end of the name referred to the fact it had 16 bit graphics. While the system itself was only 8 bit, the custom chips meant it was still a powerful machine and the graphics were remarkable for the time.
A CD add-on was released two years before the Mega CD, making the PC Engine/TurboGrafx-16 the first console capable of playing CD games. The TurboGrafx-CD received its own upgrade in the Super System Card which increased Ram to 256 KB. The Arcade Card Pro was never released outside of Japan.
The machine received a limited release in Europe, where it was known simply as the Turbografx. Very few details are available about the European version but it has been suggested that no games were ever released, leaving users with just the one game that came with the console.

emulator.description: Commercial but excellent NEC PC Engine emulator. A must.
emulator.name: Magic Engine

item.description: Pachinko Controller||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PACHINKO CONTROLLER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a pachinko controller for the PC Engine. The angled part which sticks out between the two main sections of the controller is a slider to adjust the angle of the pachinko balls as they come out. </blockquote>

computer.name: TurboGrafx-16/Turbografx

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The rear cache is removed, revealing the expansion connector.</blockquote>
